captions.text: Atmospheric.
Psychological horror.
Story rich.
Nudity.
Sexual Content.
Gore.
Psychedelic.

Whoa, you can stop now, Steam user tags, you
had me at Psychological Horror.
Well, be honest.
Nudity sealed the deal.

What&#39;s more, a title like Agony will be near
the top of my Steam library list and when

I&#39;m looking for it later I won&#39;t wear out
my scrolling finger and it will be fully prepared
for the inevitable wank.

Plus, I&#39;m impressed by the way Agony resisted
the urge to bolt an unnecessary subtitle on

the end, because it really seems like the
kind of game that would.

Like Agony: Whore of Babylon or Agony: The
Revenge of Barbie Pink.

So for all those reasons I played through
Agony, and having done so I now see another

advantage to it: the title is very easy to
do a games journalism with.
Agony: it certainly was.

Hm, hm, smug smug, let&#39;s all stroke our chins
about misogyny and then give excessive coverage
to an indie game made by someone I know.
But anyway.

Agony is a first person stealth adventure
thingy that reminded me somewhat of Sid Meier&#39;s

Jericho by Clive Barker, in that it seems
to take place in a world composed entirely
of raspberry jam.

So half the textures have that weird glisten
effect on them that look like my video card

is being swarmed by lightning bugs and every
time I move it&#39;s like I took LSD and ate pop
rocks.
The story is, you are a bloke in hell.

And none of that weaksauce metaphorical hell,
either, this is full on Hieronymous Bosch

climbing in and out of giant anuses territory,
ho yes, no symbolic confrontation with our

sins in life here, unless our sins in life
consisted of being a novelty cake designer
for lesbian S&amp;M weddings.
And your mission is to escape from hell.
At least I assume it is.

They don&#39;t tell you much at the start, all
you can do is press forward to continue exploring,

I just assume, if you&#39;re in Hell, you probably
want to be somewhere else unless you&#39;re planning
to complain about the noise.

On the way you&#39;re given directions by the
Red Goddess, a sinister temptress with her

bum out who taunts you from atop her throne
of bloodstained labias.
Remember the Lust level from Dante&#39;s Inferno?
Oh, sorry, let me take that a step back.
Remember Dante&#39;s Inferno?

The game, not the first cantica of the divine
comedy.

Yeah, that thing that had a huge marketing
push and then it came out and everyone instantly
forgot about it.

Well there was a level themed around lust
in it, and Agony is basically that multiplied

fifty times and with a big bucket of the pink
slime from Ghostbusters 2 thrown over it.

Agony makes me think that the phrase &quot;Psychological
Horror&quot; is getting bandied around a bit too
easily these days.

Psychological horror to me means something
with more of an understated creeping dread
about it, more &quot;Euhhhh!&quot;
than &quot;Eurgh!&quot;
And Agony is very much more on the &quot;Eurgh!&quot;
side of things.
Yeah, fucking transcribe that one, bitch.

There is very little &#39;psychological&#39; about
the horror involved in being in a room made

of bones as human tripe pours from nipple-shaped
wall dispensers and we have to tread carefully

to avoid getting chased down and torn to shreds
by big-titted demons with heads shaped like
vaginas.

Well I suppose that&#39;s a little bit psychological,
in the sense that the art designer should
probably talk to a psychologist.

Preferably one behind a whip and a chair and
an inch of reinforced glass.

Your main objective throughout the plot is
&quot;find the Red Goddess.&quot;

Which you succeed in doing multiple times
but it never seems to take.

&quot;Oh you found me, go find me again, I&#39;m over
there now, in that temple on the crest of
that distant hill shaped like a giant buttock.&quot;

And in keeping with the Tom Clancy&#39;s Jericho
comparison, we have the ability to come back

as a ghost after death and possess any damned
soul who isn&#39;t wearing a bag on their head,

necromancy being powerless against the divine
magic of burlap.

So every other person hanging around the level
get to be your extra lives, which they probably

didn&#39;t picture for their futures during their
sessions with the high school guidance counsellor
but that&#39;s hell for you.

These basic mechanics aren&#39;t terribly well
explained.

When I first saw the contextual icon for &quot;take
bag off head&quot; I thought it was the icon for
&quot;push person over.&quot;

And since the person was standing on the edge
of a cliff at the time I was like &quot;Geez, there&#39;s

no need for that kind of pettiness, this is
Hell, not a staff meeting at a failing startup.&quot;

Eventually I figured it out, but I suspect
the basic mechanics weren&#39;t terribly well
explained to most of the developers, either.
&quot;We&#39;re doing a stealth game?
I always forget what that means.

I guess it means that if you try to move quickly
past the vagina face monster then it hears

you and bites your face off, but if you carefully
move slowly past it then it will also hear
you and chew your throat out?

Erm, no, I think you&#39;re missing some of the
basic principles, there, Agony.
Oh right.

Now about those hiding places, I&#39;m pretty
sure I know how this works.

You&#39;re running away from vagina mush, you
quickly get into a hiding place, then vagina

mush catches up, spots you instantly and masticates
your nipples off.

Wait, I confused myself, what were we talking
about?

Most of these hiding places are also impossible
to recognise as such until you&#39;re standing
right over them and the contextual icon appears.

They&#39;re little piles of cartilage pancakes
against a background of more cartilage pancakes.

See, the cluttered environment design is making
all the important stuff get lost in the noise,

when it&#39;s not actively halting me in my tracks
because my hitbox got caught on an extruding

canker thus allowing the pursuing vagina monster
to catch up and nibble me pancreas out.

And yet environments are simultaneously too
busy and extremely boring.

Turn things up to 11 and stay there and it&#39;s
just as dull as staying at one.
Repetition, you see.

Seen one pulsating ulcerated jawbone with
little tiny bellends instead of molars, seen
&#39;em all.

So what other mechanics have been thrown into
this big undisciplined bucket of liquidised
offal of a game?

Well, after a while you can possess the vagina
monsters as well as the humans.

Don&#39;t know why you&#39;d fucking want to, since
only the humans are allowed to pick up items

and work the puzzles that are necessary for
making progress so all you can do is run back

and forth around the current map trying to
find something to kill yourself with, or failing

that stand in front of a mirror for a while
jiggling up and down.

Also there are a grand total of three character
upgrades as token as the wheelchair bound
dude from the Burger King Kids Club.

&quot;Increase how long the player can hold their
breath&quot;?
Oh, there&#39;s a hold breath button!

Now I understand, I&#39;m supposed to hold my
breath as I move slowly past the vagina monsters

so they won&#39;t - oh it spotted me anyway and
gnawed my gonads off.
Never mind.

In truth, the actual core gameplay mechanic
of Agony is &quot;press forward to continue,&quot; and

everything that&#39;s layered onto that like flakes
of greaseproof paper on a turd, stealth, puzzles,

collectibles, labyrinthine maps, all of that
is annoyance and busywork so we can say it&#39;s
not just a walking simulator.
What was the idea, setting out on this, Agony?
To make a fun game?
Pa ha ha but seriously.

Were you trying to shock me with all your
gore and tits?

&#39;Cos you failed, there&#39;s no relatable humanity
to give the shocking stuff context, we might

as well be watching you smear ground beef
on a real doll.

&quot;Alright, fine, we just wanted to draw some
bums and process unresolved feelings about

when our teenage babysitter made us go to
bed early.&quot;
Well that I respect.

But piss off now, Agony, you&#39;re dripping pussy
juice on the afghan.
